issues.description: The problem statement inconsistently refers to the animal feeding method using two different names: the UML and many tasks use messageOnFeed(), but several places in the textual instructions refer to getFeedingSound(). This mismatch in the method name/signature will confuse students about which method to implement and which method the Farm should call (feedAllAnimals() / singFarmSongVerse). The provided solution and template expect messageOnFeed(), so the occurrences of getFeedingSound() in the problem text are contradictory and could block or mislead students.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across the problem statement, template, and solution. Replace all occurrences of getFeedingSound() in the problem text with messageOnFeed(), and update any descriptive lines that mention getFeedingSound() (e.g., in Part 2 and Part 3) to refer to messageOnFeed(). Alternatively, if you prefer the name getFeedingSound(), update the UML, template stubs, and solution to use getFeedingSound() (and ensure Animal declares that abstract method and implementations override it). The simplest fix: standardize on messageOnFeed() in the problem text.

issues.description: The problem statement's Part 2 (tasks for Seal, Pig, Goat) refers to a method named `getFeedingSound()` for the animals, while the UML and the solution use `messageOnFeed()` as the abstract feed-method name on Animal (and concrete classes implement `messageOnFeed()`). This mismatch can mislead students into implementing `getFeedingSound()` (which the template/tests do not expect) or being uncertain which method name to use, creating unnecessary confusion when mapping the textual requirements to the provided/template code and the tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method name across the problem statement and code. Replace the `getFeedingSound()` mentions in the problem text (Part 2 for Seal, Pig, Goat) with `messageOnFeed()` so the textual tasks match the UML and the template/solution. For example: "The method messageOnFeed() should return \"Arf Arf!\" for Seal (and similarly for Pig/Goat)."
